repnme.cdata!:
India - Integrated Watershed Development -
            Hills - and - Plains - Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The audit concurs with the
            Implementation Completion Report's ratings of both the
            Integrated Watershed Development (Hills), and (Plains)
            Projects, assessing satisfactory outcomes, likely
            sustainability, and substantial institutional development
            impacts. Regardless of success, lessons drawn from the
            projects indicate the practicality of watershed, or
            sub-watershed units, within which to plan, and implement
            natural resource management projects in rain-fed areas,
            since collective efforts by the community, focus on
            improvements in water availability, with immediate impacts
            on their livelihoods. In addition, these communal efforts,
            are essential in conveying the sense of ownership by
            beneficiaries, which should be strengthened by the
            collaborative partnership between project staff, and
            beneficiaries. Maybe, this requires a change of perspective,
            particularly by project staff, to enhance participatory
            methodologies. It is important to note, that for the various
            government services departments (soil conservation,
            forestry, agriculture, and animal husbandry) to be
            sustainable beyond project completion, the establishment,
            for instance, of village development committees, with
            permanent, lasting arrangements with governments, would
            facilitate incentives in an integrated approach. Similarly,
            sustainable long-term conservation objectives require the
            realization of short-term benefits from project interventions.

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall assessment is that the
            project outcome was satisfactory. Both World Bank and
            Borrower performances were satisfactory. Project
            sustainability is likely. Lessons included the following:
            States needed sufficient time and support at the beginning
            of projects to set up planning procedures and systems and to
            fully involve the communities in defining their needs and
            involvement. The success of constituted user groups
            emphasized the importance of the government strongly
            supporting and promoting the establishment and involvement
            of local village organizations. This project's success
            depended on project design including community awareness
            building, farmer and community training, savings schemes
            promotion, and interventions that provided short-, as well
            as medium- and long-term benefits to individual farmers and
            communities. On the other hand, technical support for the
            project was too narrowly confined to adaptive agricultural
            research. The project gave little direct emphasis to
            women's needs and aspirations; it should have focused
            on forming specific women user groups, and training women in
            village-based income-generating activities. Policy and
            action plans should have emphasized restrictimg livestock
            numbers, combined with more active programs to exclude
            grazing and rehabilitate forest areas. Benefits would have
            acrued with more inter-agency collaboration. Lastly,
            nongovernmental organizations should have been participated
            in initial planning and received training.
